JournalInfo.JournalSubTitle: Journal of Radiation Oncology, Biology, Physics

ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Reirradiation for recurrent head and neck cancer with salvage interstitial pulsed-dose-rate brachytherapy
Re-Bestrahlung bei rezidivierenden HNO-Tumoren mit interstitieller Salvage Pulsed-dose-rate-Brachytherapie

AbstractSection.Heading: Purpose
AbstractSection.Para: To assess the long-term results of protocol-based interstitial pulsed-dose-rate (PDR) brachytherapy as reirradiation combined with simultaneous chemotherapy and interstitial hyperthermia in selected patients with recurrent head and neck tumors.

AbstractSection.Heading: Materials and methods
AbstractSection.Para: A total of 104 patients with biopsy-proven recurrent head and neck cancer were treated with interstitial PDR brachytherapy. Salvage surgery had also been undergone by 53/104 (51 %) patients (R1 or R2 resection in > 80 % of patients). Salvage brachytherapy alone was administered in 81 patients (78 %), with a median total dose of 56.7 Gy. Salvage brachytherapy in combination with external beam radiotherapy (EBRT) was performed in 23/104 patients (32 %), using a median total dose of DREF = 24 Gy. Simultaneously to PDR brachytherapy, concomitant chemotherapy was administered in 58/104 (55.8 %) patients. A single session of interstitial hyperthermia was also used to treat 33/104 (31.7 %) patients. The analysis was performed after a median follow-up of 60 months.

AbstractSection.Heading: Results
AbstractSection.Para: Calculated according to Kaplan–Meier, local tumor control rates after 2, 5, and 10 years were 92.5, 82.4, and 58.9 %, respectively. Comparing results of salvage PDR brachytherapy with or without simultaneous chemotherapy, the 10-year local control rates were 76 vs. 39 % (p= 0014), respectively. No other patient- or treatment-related parameters had a significant influence on treatment results. Soft tissue necrosis or bone necrosis developed in 18/104 (17.3 %) and 11/104 (9.6 %) patients, respectively, but only 3 % of patients required surgical treatment.

AbstractSection.Heading: Conclusion
AbstractSection.Para: PDR interstitial brachytherapy with simultaneous chemotherapy is a very effective and, in experienced hands, also a safe treatment modality in selected patients with head and neck cancer in previously irradiated areas.

AbstractSection.Heading: Hintergrund und Ziel
AbstractSection.Para: Es erfolgte die Analyse der Langzeitergebnisse einer protokollbasierten interstitiellen Brachytherapie (Re-Bestrahlung) mit simultaner Chemotherapie und interstitieller Hyperthermie bei selektierten Patienten mit HNO-Rezidivtumoren.

AbstractSection.Heading: Patienten und Methoden
AbstractSection.Para: Insgesamt wurden 104 Patienten mit histologisch gesichertem Rezidiv eines HNO-Karzinoms mit einer interstitiellen PDR („pulsed-dose-rate“)-Brachytherapie behandelt: 53/104 (51 %) Patienten unterzogen sich auch einer Salvage-Chirurgie (bei > 80 % der Patienten R1/R2-Resektion); 81 Patienten (78 %) wurden mit einer alleinigen Salvage-Brachytherapie bis zu einer Gesamtreferenzdosis von 56,7 Gy (Median) behandelt. Eine Salvage-Brachytherapie in Kombination mit einer perkutanen Strahlentherapie wurde bei 23/104 Patienten (32 %) mit einer Gesamtreferenzdosis in Höhe von Dref=24 Gy durchgeführt. Eine simultane Chemotherapie wurde bei 58/104 (55,8 %) Patienten verabreicht; 33/104 (31,7 %) Patienten wurden ergänzend mit einer interstitiellen Hyperthermie behandelt. Die Analyse wurde nach einem Follow-up im Median von 60 Monaten durchgeführt.

AbstractSection.Heading: Ergebnisse
AbstractSection.Para: Die lokalen Tumorkontrollraten nach Kaplan-Meier lagen nach 2, 5 und 10 Jahren bei 92,5, 82,4 und 58,9 %. Im Vergleich der Ergebnisse der Salvage-PDR-Brachytherapie mit oder ohne simultaner Chemotherapie waren die lokalen 10-Jahres-Tumorkontrollraten bei 76 vs. 39 % (p= 0014). Keine anderen patientenbezogenen oder therapiebezogenen Parameter hatten einen signifikanten Einfluss auf die Therapieergebnisse. Bei 18/104 (17,3 %) und 11/104 (9,6 %) Patienten haben wir Weichteil- oder Osteoradionekrosen beobachtet, allerdings war nur bei 3 % der Patienten auch eine chirurgische Therapie erforderlich.

AbstractSection.Heading: Schlussfolgerung
AbstractSection.Para: Die PDR-interstitielle Brachytherapie mit einer simultanen Chemotherapie ist eine sehr effektive und in erfahrenen Händen auch eine sichere Behandlungsmodalität für selektierte Patienten mit HNO-Rezidivtumoren in bereits bestrahlten Arealen.

Body.Para: Treatment possibilities for patients with locally recurrent head and neck tumors are limited and, as a consequence, the results are mostly disappointing [1–4]. Surgical resection with clear resection margins is rarely possible and because of previous radiation therapy, the scope for reirradiation is also significantly limited. In cases where the radiation oncologist performs reirradiation despite the risks, the setting is usually palliative; consequently, the results of such treatments are very disappointing [3, 5, 6]. However, as part of a multimodal approach with simultaneous chemotherapy, interstitial hyperthermia, and—where possible and considered clinically useful—in combination with limited surgery, interstitial brachytherapy can be a treatment strategy with curative potential. The aim of the present analysis is to assess the long-term results of protocol-based interstitial pulsed-dose-rate (PDR) brachytherapy combined with simultaneous chemotherapy and interstitial hyperthermia in a group of selected patients.

Section2.Heading: Patient selection
Section2.Para: Between 1999 and September 2008, 104 patients with biopsy-proven recurrent head and neck cancer were treated with interstitial PDR brachytherapy at our department.

Eligibility criteria for protocol-based salvage brachytherapy ± simultaneous chemotherapy and interstitial hyperthermia were as follows: histologically confirmed recurrent carcinoma of the head and neck region with no evidence of distant metastasis; tumor size and location suitable for brachytherapy techniques; good performance status and radiation therapy completed more than 3 months previously. Treatment was conducted according the principles of the Helsinki Declaration of 1975 (in its most recently amended version) and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

Before diagnosis of tumor recurrence and in the context of their previous antitumor treatment, all patients had received radiation therapy up to a total dose of 58–76 Gy (median total dose 65 Gy), with or without chemotherapy. The median time interval between the first and second radiation therapy—i.e. retreatment with brachytherapy—was 30 months (range 3–293 months).

Of the total cohort, 27/104 (26 %) patients were treated for secondary primaries and 77/104 (74 %) for recurrent tumors. Detailed patient characteristics relating to tumor site and stage (Table 1) show that the majority of patients had tumors of the oral cavity (59 %) and large tumors (80 %).

Section2.Heading: Treatment
Section2.Para: Salvage surgery had been undergone by 53/104 (51 %) patients. The status of the resection margins was assessed in all cases: unfortunately, microscopic (R1) or macroscopic (R2) residual disease was found in 19 % (10/53) and 62 % (33/53) of patients, respectively, before the start of salvage interstitial brachytherapy.

All patients were treated with interstitial PDR brachytherapy with or without external beam radiotherapy (EBRT). The implant method has been described in detail previously [7, 8]. In all cases, the dose was specified according to International Commission on Radiation Units (ICRU) 58 (Paris system; [9]). A dose per pulse (dp) of 0.40–0.70 Gy (median 0.55 Gy) was administered up to a median total dose of 55 Gy (ranging between 10 Gy and 66.3 Gy). The pulses were delivered for 24 h per day, with a time interval of 1 h between two pulses. The median implant volume, as measured by the volume of the reference 85 % isodose, was 26.3 cm3 (range 7.3–77.1 cm3). Further documented brachytherapy parameters included the volume receiving >150% of the prescribed dose (V150), the dose nonuniformity ratio (DNR), the coverage index (V100), and the D90. Their median values were 7.1 cm3, 0.26, 92.9, and 98.5 %, respectively.

Of the total group, 81 patients (78 %) received salvage brachytherapy alone, using a median total dose of 56.7 Gy with dp values in the range of 0.45–0.7 Gy/h/24 h (median 0.55 Gy/h). Salvage brachytherapy in combination with EBRT was performed in 23 patients (32 %), using a median total dose of DREF = 24 Gy (dpmedian = 0.5 Gy, range 0.4–0.7 Gy). Brachytherapy was administered after a median of 7 days after EBRT. EBRT was performed up to a median reference dose of 40 Gy (range 20–67 Gy).

Simultaneously to PDR brachytherapy, concomitant chemotherapy was administered in 58/104 (55.8 %) patients. From day 1 to day 5 of PDR brachytherapy, the majority of patients received one course of cisplatin (20 mg/m2) or carboplatin (AUC1) as a short intravenous infusion each day, and 5-flourouracil 800 mg/m2 was given by continuous infusion for 120 h. In 4 patients, chemotherapy regimens with cisplatin/paclitaxel or cisplatin/mitomycin were used for individual reasons.

In 33/104 (31.7 %) patients, a single session of interstitial hyperthermia was administered directly after PDR brachytherapy was finished. Interstitial dipole antennas (6–11, median 7) were used to deliver treatment and multipoint temperature sensors were used to measure the temperature. Each patient was maintained at the target temperature for a median of 60 min. The median temperature attained was 42.0 °C.

All patients were followed up closely to analyze acute and late toxicity, local control, and survival. The analysis was performed after a median follow-up of 60 months (24–162 months). The median follow-up was calculated from the first day of reirradiation to the date of the last follow-up.

The primary endpoints of the study were analysis of local tumor control rates and late side effects. As a secondary endpoint the Kaplan–Meier analysis was performed to estimate disease-free and overall survival after 5 years.

Section2.Heading: Assessment of tumor response and side effects
Section2.Para: All patients underwent repeated examinations during and after therapy for evaluation of tumor response and side effects. Following completion of treatment, patients were followed at 3-month intervals for 24 months and at 6-months intervals thereafter for at least a further 36 months, to analyze late side effects, local control, and survival. The side effects were scored according to Lent Soma criteria.

Section2.Heading: Statistics
Section2.Para: Data management and statistics were carried out with PASW Statistics for MS Windows (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA), release 18.0.0. For statistical comparisons between groups, the Mann–Whitney U and Pearson’s χ-square tests were used, as appropriate. Survival probability was estimated using the Kaplan–Meier method [10], using the log-rank test and Cox regression multivariate analyses to compare two or more groups.

Section1.Heading: Results
Section1.Para: All the patients received the entire intended course of salvage PDR brachytherapy ± simultaneous chemotherapy and hyperthermia. There were no treatment-related deaths.

After a median follow-up of 60 months, the 2-, 5-, and 10-year local tumor control rates calculated according to Kaplan–Meier were 92.5, 82.4, and 58.9 %, respectively (Fig. 1). The 5-year disease-free and overall survival rates were 81 and 21 %, respectively. A detailed analysis of causes of deaths shows that 4 % of patients died on other tumor, 12 % on metastases, 54 % on other causesand only minority of all patients (30%) died on local recurrent tumor.
Fig. 1
Local recurrence-free survival rates according to Kaplan–Meier

When comparing patients treated for second primaries and patients with recurrent tumors, we found a difference in 5-year local recurrence-free survival rates (70 vs. 46 %, respectively), but this difference was not statistically significant (p= 0.63). Similarly, we found no statistically significant difference (neither in log-rank test nor in multivariate Cox proportional hazards regression analysis) in the probability of local recurrence in patients subgrouped by different brachytherapy quality parameters, by anatomical site of the tumor, tumor size, resection margins clear versus positive, tumor histology, lymph nodes positive versus negative, tumor grade, or lymphangitis carcinomatosa. Additionally, the application of hyperthermia did not have a significant influence on treatment results. In contrast, the simultaneous application of chemotherapy during PDR brachytherapy significantly improved treatment results.

Comparing results of salvage PDR brachytherapy with or without simultaneous chemotherapy, the 10-year local control rates according to Kaplan–Meier were 76 vs. 39 % (p= 0.014), respectively (Fig. 2). Simultaneous chemotherapy was the only factor shown to have an influence on the local recurrence rates achieved by salvage brachytherapy, as was also confirmed using multivariate Cox proportional hazards regression analysis (p= 0015).
Fig. 2
Local recurrence-free survival rates according to Kaplan–Meier in patients with or without simultaneous chemotherapy (blue line brachytherapy without chemotherapy, red line brachytherapy with chemotherapy; p= 0.01)

Regarding serious late side effects, 18/104 (17.3 %) patients developed soft tissue necrosis, but only 3 (3/104, 2.9 %) developed soft tissue ulceration needing surgical treatment. Furthermore, in 11/104 (9.6 %) patients, we observed radiation-induced bone necrosis, but only in 3 patients (3/104, 2.9 %) was surgical treatment necessary.

All patients scheduled for simultaneous chemotherapy received the intended dose of chemotherapy. Generally, simultaneous chemotherapy was well tolerated, with only transient side effects. Bone marrow suppression manifested as leucopenia, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. We observed no grade III or IV side effects.

Section1.Heading: Discussion
Section1.Para: The majority of patients with persistent or recurrent head and neck cancer have a very poor prognosis. Retreating these patients with salvage surgery or salvage radiation therapy carries a significant risk of morbidity. Radiation therapy of head and neck cancer in previously irradiated areas is a complicated treatment, associated with a significant risk of serious acute and late side effects [3, 5, 8, 11–13]. Although salvage EBRT (re-EBRT) is technically possible, it is rarely attempted because of its low effectiveness and the associated high complication rates [4, 14–16] Therefore, the majority of patients are treated with palliative or supportive care only. However, if selected carefully, a reasonable number of these patients may have a chance of long-term disease control. By virtue of the strictly focal application of radiation dose and the very steep dose dropoff in the neighboring tissues, brachytherapy can offer selected patients the possibility of reirradiation up to high doses (@ 60 Gy), without unavoidably high complication rates in the surrounding healthy tissues. There is still no clear evidence on whether simultaneous hyperthermia or concomitant chemotherapy can improve the results of brachytherapy [5, 17–19]. Only very scant data relating to the combination of brachytherapy with chemotherapy and interstitial hyperthermia are available in the literature [5, 20–22] and unfortunately, none of these analyses have found significant improvement in the results of salvage brachytherapy. Generally speaking, the reported local control rates of salvage brachytherapy for previously irradiated recurrent head and neck cancer vary very widely—between 14 and 90 % after 2–5 years [23–29].

Only few groups [30–33] have reported very good local control rates of up to 80 % using salvage brachytherapy. Mazeron et al. [30] described local control rates of up to 72 % at 2 years in previously irradiated patients. In 73 patients with velotonsillar carcinoma in a previously irradiated field, Peiffert et al. [32] reported 5-year actuarial local control rates of 80 and 67 % for T1 N0 and T2 N0, respectively (only grade 2 complications occurred in 13 % of patients). Narayna et al. [33] and Pommier et al. [31] described equally good results in a small patient group. Our earlier published results [34–36] proved that the combination of PDR brachytherapy with simultaneous chemotherapy and interstitial hyperthermia leads to high local control rates (up to 79 %) accompanied with acceptable rates of serious late side effects (10–18 %).

In contrast to these excellent results, some other groups have reported significant severe late side effects after salvage brachytherapy as reirradiation [1, 3, 21, 37–39]. Puthawala et al. [25], Mazeron et al. [30], and Levendag et al. [40] reported moderate or severe side effects complications were in 27–28 %. Bartochowska et al. [5] stated an overall complication rate of 35 % after salvage brachytherapy with palliative intention. Other authors reported even higher rates of severe side effects in up to 60 % of patients [1–3, 21, 37–39, 41–43]. In this context, one important fact should be borne in mind: serious late side effects appear more often after high-dose-rate (HDR) salvage brachytherapy than after PDR-salvage brachytherapy [5, 8, 40, 44–47].

Regarding effectiveness (5-year local control rate of about 80 %) and the rate of side effects (soft tissue necrosis 3–17 % and bone necrosis 3–10 %), the current results are quite comparable with the best previously published results [31, 32, 44, 48]. We believe that the following features of our treatment concept are crucial: the use of brachytherapy as PDR brachytherapy (as is generally known, PDR brachytherapy is a modality which unites the biological advantages of low-dose-rate, LDR, brachytherapy and the technologic advantages of HDR brachytherapy), stringent quality assurance [7, 8, 49, 50, 51], and use of simultaneous chemotherapy. Whether the use of hyperthermia can also significantly improve the efficacy of salvage interstitial brachytherapy, is not clear. In order to address the later issue, more patients are necessary for valid statistical analysis.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: PDR interstitial brachytherapy with simultaneous chemotherapy is a very effective and, in experienced hands, also a safe treatment modality in selected patients with head and neck cancer in previously irradiated areas.

FormalPara.Heading: Conflict of interest
FormalPara.Para: V. Strnad, M. Lotter, S. Kreppner, and R. Fietkau state that there are no conflicts of interest. All studies on humans described in the present manuscript were carried out with the approval of the responsible ethics committee and in accordance with national law and the Helsinki Declaration of 1975 (in its current, revised form). Informed consent was obtained from all patients included in studies.
